name: Chae.Tree

values.name: deepFilter
values.comment:
Similar to `filter` but includes node when some of its child matches.

    tree = [ Node.node "5" 5 [ Node.node "1" 1 [ Node.singleton "9" 9 ], Node.singleton "10" 10 ] ]

    deepFilter ((<) 6) tree == [[ Node.node "5" 5 ([ Node.node "1" 1 ([ Node.node "9" 9 [] ]), Node.node "10" 10 [] ]) ]]
    deepFilter ((<) 11) tree == []
    deepFilter ((<) 0) tree == tree
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree a

values.name: filter
values.comment:
Filter Tree.
Similar to `List.filter` but working on trees.
If parent node do not pass condition its children are no included in result

    tree = [Node.node "5" 5 [ Node.singleton "1" 1, Node.singleton "10" 10 ] ]

    filter ((<) 4) tree == [ Node "5" 5 ([Node "10" 10 []]) ]
    filter ((<) 6) tree == []
    filter ((<) 0) tree == tree
values.type: (a -> Bool) -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree a

values.name: fromList
values.type: (a -> Chae.Id.Id) -> (a -> List Chae.Id.Id) -> List a -> Chae.Tree.Tree a

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map function over tree
Similar to `List.map` but working with trees
values.type: (a -> b) -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree b

values.name: map2
values.comment:
Map function over two trees to produce new tree from both combined
Similar to `List.map2` but working with trees
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree b -> Chae.Tree.Tree c

values.name: nil
values.comment:
Construct empty tree
Alias for []
values.type: Chae.Tree.Tree a

values.name: push
values.comment:
Produce new tree with given item pushed under its parent.
First argument is function from item to `Id/String`.

Second argument is `Maybe Id` is ether:

  - `Nothing` => push to root

  - `Just parentId` => push to sub Tree

    push toId Nothing 1 [] == [Node "1" 1 []]
    push toId (Just (toId 1)) 2 [ Node.singleton "1" 1 ] == [Node "1" 1 ([Node "2" 2 []])]
values.type: (a -> Chae.Id.Id) -> Maybe.Maybe Chae.Id.Id -> a -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree a

values.name: reduce
values.comment:
Reduce Tree by given function
Similar to `List.foldr` but working with trees
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> b

values.name: subTreeFor
values.comment:
Returns sub `Tree` and ancestors for given `Id` and `Tree`.
First argument is `Maybe Id` is ether:

  - `Nothing` => result is given tree (with empty ancestors `List`).
  - `Just parentId` => result is sub tree for node with `id == parentId`.

Returns tuple containing sub tree and list of ancestors of that sub tree (from parent to root).

    items =
        [ { id = 1, name = "first", parentIds = [] }
        , { id = 2, name = "child", parentIds = [1] }
        , { id = 3, name = "dep categories", parentIds = [2] }
        ]

     itemId item =
         toId (.id item )

     itemParentIds item =
         .parentIds item |> List.map toId

     tree =
        fromList itemId itemParentIds items

     subTreeFor Nothing tree == (tree, [])
     subTreeFor (Just "1") tree == ([Node "2" { id = 2, name = "child", parentIds = [1] } ([Node "3" { id = 3, name = "dep categories", parentIds = [2] } []])],[{ id = 1, name = "first", parentIds = [] }])
     subTreeFor (Just "2") tree == ([Node "3" { id = 3, name = "dep categories", parentIds = [2] } []],[{ id = 2, name = "child", parentIds = [1] },{ id = 1, name = "first", parentIds = [] }])
values.type: Maybe.Maybe Chae.Id.Id -> Chae.Tree.Tree a -> ( Chae.Tree.Tree a, List a )

values.name: zip
values.comment:
Zip two trees to tree of tuple
Similar to `List.zip` but working with trees
values.type: Chae.Tree.Tree a -> Chae.Tree.Tree b -> Chae.Tree.Tree ( a, b )

name: Chae.Node

values.name: addChild
values.comment:
Return `Node` with item add as sub `Node`.
First argument is function from item to `Id/String`.

    addChild "2" 2 (singleton "1" 1) == Node "1" 1 ([Node "2" 2 []])
    addChild "3" 3 (addChild "2" 2 (singleton "1" 1)) == Node "1" 1 ([Node "3" 3 [],Node "2" 2 []])
values.type: Chae.Id.Id -> a -> Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Node.Node a

values.name: children
values.comment:
Get child tree of `Node`.
This is common way to access sub tree of given node.

    children (singleton "1" 1) == []
    children (addChild "2" 2 (singleton "1" 1)) == [Node "2" 2 []]
values.type: Chae.Node.Node a -> List (Chae.Node.Node a)

values.name: flatMap
values.comment:
Map and flatten

    n = node "1" 1 [ node "2" 2 [], node "3" 3 [ node "4" 4 []]]

    flatMap (\a -> node "2" (a * 2) []) n == Node "1" 2 ([Node "2" 4 [],Node "3" 6 ([Node "4" 8 []])])
    flatMap (\a -> node "2" (a * 2) [ node  "1" (a * 3) [] ] ) m == Node "1" 2 ([Node "1" 3 [],Node "2" 4 ([Node "1" 6 []]),Node "3" 6 ([Node "1" 9 [],Node "4" 8 ([Node "1" 12 []])])])
values.type: (a -> Chae.Node.Node b) -> Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Node.Node b

values.name: flatten
values.comment: Flatten Node of Nodes to Node.
values.type: Chae.Node.Node (Chae.Node.Node a) -> Chae.Node.Node a

values.name: hasChildren
values.comment:
Check if tree has children

    hasChildren (singleton "1" 1) == False
    hasChildren (addChild "2" 2 (singleton "1" 1)) == True
values.type: Chae.Node.Node a -> Bool

values.name: id
values.comment:
Get id of given `Node`.

    id (singleton "1" 1) == "1"
    id (singleton "uid" { a = "a"} ) == "uid"
values.type: Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Id.Id

values.name: map
values.comment:
Map function on tree
produces new modified tree

    map ((+) 1) (addChild "2" 2 (singleton "1" 1)) == Node "1" 2 ([Node "2" 3 []])
values.type: (a -> b) -> Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Node.Node b

values.name: map2
values.comment: Similar to map, but takes two Nodes and produce new one by combining items of both
values.type: (a -> b -> c) -> Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Node.Node b -> Chae.Node.Node c

values.name: node
values.comment:
Create node. Alias for Node constructor (which was opaque in previous releases)

    node "1" 1 [] == Node "1" 1 []
    node "1" 1 [ node "2" 2 [] ] == Node "1" 1 ([Node "2" 2 []])
values.type: Chae.Id.Id -> b -> List (Chae.Node.Node b) -> Chae.Node.Node b

values.name: pushDeep
values.comment:
Find parent node in children by id and push new item to it

    n = node "1" 1 [ node "2" 2 [], node "3" 3 [ node "4" 4 []]]

    pushDeep "4" "10" 10 n == Node "1" 1 ([Node "2" 2 [],Node "3" 3 ([Node "4" 4 ([Node "10" 10 []])])])
values.type: Chae.Id.Id -> Chae.Id.Id -> a -> Chae.Node.Node a -> Chae.Node.Node a

values.name: reduce
values.comment:
Reduce Node by given function. Similar to `List.foldr`

    reduce (+) 0 (addChild "20" 20 (singleton "1" 1)) == 21
    reduce (*) 1 (addChild "3" 3 (singleton "4" 4)) == 12
values.type: (a -> b -> b) -> b -> Chae.Node.Node a -> b

values.name: root
values.comment:
Turns `Node` back to value it was created from.

This function provide recommended way to access user space data while working with tree.

    root (singleton "1" "Elm") == "Elm"
    root (singleton "1" { id = "1", name = "Elm" }) == { id = "1", name = "Elm" }
values.type: Chae.Node.Node a -> a

values.name: singleton
values.comment:
Create empty `Node` for given values.
First paramter is function which takes given value and return it's id.

    singleton "1" 1 == Node "1" 1 []
    singleton "1" { a = "b" } == Node "1" { a = "b" } []
values.type: Chae.Id.Id -> a -> Chae.Node.Node a

values.name: toTuple
values.comment:
Transform node to tuple of `( id, item, children )`

    toTuple (singleton "1" 1) == ("1",1,[])
    toTuple (node "1" 1 [(singleton "2" 2)]) == ("1",1,[Node "2" 2 []])
values.type: Chae.Node.Node a -> ( Chae.Id.Id, a, List (Chae.Node.Node a) )

name: Chae.Id

values.name: toId
values.comment:
Convert any value to `Id` type.
This is just alias for `toString` function.

    toId "str" = "\"str\""
    toId 1 = "1"
    toId { a = "a" } = "{ a = \"a\" }"
values.type: a -> Chae.Id.Id
